channel.title: Religion and Ethics News@Emory
channel.description: All the latest news from Emory University.

item.title: Emory Professor Honored for Work With Incarcerated Women
item.description: When Elizabeth M. Bounds of Emory University's Candler School of Theology followed her call, it landed her in jail - voluntarily.

item.title: Emory Ethicist Nominated for World Technology Award
item.description: Paul Root Wolpe, director of Emory University's Center for Ethics, has been named a finalist for a prestigious World Technology Award in Ethics, to be presented by the World Technology Network at the United Nations next week.

item.title: Conference Calls Preachers to Find Their Own Voice Within Tweet Culture
item.description: Rev. Otis Moss III, senior pastor of Trinity United Church of Christ in Chicago, bluntly told a chapel full of pastors gathered yesterday at Emory University that Tweeting and other digital media are tools they need to embrace: "There is a lot of 8-track preaching in an MP3 world."

item.title: United Methodist Alumni Honored by Emory's Candler School of Theology
item.description: Emory University's Candler School of Theology is honoring three Distinguished Alumni Award recipients for 2011, including a pastor who has bettered the lives and homes of needy families for more than 30 years, a Candler icon who remains a school leader six decades after he graduated, and a clergyman who is guiding the work of more than 60 United Methodist Churches in the Southeast.

item.title: Music and Worship Certificate Now Offered by Emory's Candler School of Theology
item.description: Emory University's Candler School of Theology is offering a new Certificate in Music and Worship, providing worship and music leaders the opportunity to study closely with the esteemed theologians and musicians on Candler's faculty.

item.title: Richey, Holifield Receive Emeritus Recognition
item.description: Emory University's Candler School of Theology is honoring two distinguished retired faculty members with emeritus status.

item.title: Religious Freedom Faces Great Challenges, Says Glendon
item.description: Harvard Law Professor Mary Ann Glendon, speaking recently at Emory University, raises a broad concern about religious freedom in America.

item.title: Jewish Law Supports Reproductive Technologies, Says Emory Professor
item.description: Jewish law supports current and emerging forms of biotechnology used in assisted reproduction - including artificial insemination, surrogacy, embryo screening and even more debatable techniques - as long as the overriding intent is to "produce a healthy or healthier child," says Rabbi Michael J. Broyde, professor of law at Emory University.

item.title: Reformation Day Celebrates Luther's Role in King James Bible
item.description: Emory University's Candler School of Theology celebrates the 400th anniversary of the publication of the King James Bible and welcomes Jürgen Moltmann, one of the world's most prominent theologians, to campus for its 24th annual Reformation Day celebration Oct. 27

item.title: Emory Gathers Great Pastors to Share the 'Art of Preaching' Oct. 10-12
item.description: Thomas G. Long of Candler School of Theology and seven other preaching stars will share their creative processes and techniques.

item.title: Jewish Perspectives on 9/11 Focus of New Book
item.description: As the 10th anniversary of 9/11 approaches, a new book titled "Contending With Catastrophe: Jewish Perspectives on September 11th," edited by Jewish law expert Michael Broyde of Emory University, is a reminder that the events of that day raised issues no one could have anticipated.

item.title: Author James Carroll to Speak on 'Jesus Against Himself'
item.description: Award-winning author and Boston Globe columnist James Carroll will give four free public lectures at Emory University this fall on the theme "Jesus Against Himself: From Itinerant Galilean to Christ of God and Back Again."

item.title: 9/11 Expert: U.S. Foreign Policy, Muslim Attitudes Toward the U.S.
item.description: Law professor Abdullahi An-Na'im is an expert in Islam, Human Rights and Shari'a. An-Na'im discusses how U.S. foreign policy changed in the wake of 9/11 and how Muslim peoples around the world feel about the U.S.

item.title: 9/11 Expert: American Tolerance of Muslims
item.description: Vincent Cornell, professor of Middle Eastern and Islamic Studies, is an expert in contemporary islamic reform, extremism, Islam and the West, Muslim-Christian relations and stereotypes. Cornell discusses whether Americans are more or less tolerant of Muslims since 9/11 and how the world can get past Islamophobia.

item.title: 9/11 Expert: Jewish Perspectives
item.description: Emory Law professor Michael Broyde is an expert in Jewish law and ethics, comparative religious law and editor of the new book, "Contending with Catastrophe: Jewish Perspectives on September 11th."
